author: Ravi Shankar Rajan

comments.comment: Suggested resource/reference: "A handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship" - Robert Martin.

quotes.quote: ...the first thoughts of any developer are hardly clear. The code will be probably a clutter of muddy ideas and syntax. It will be essentially the first draft.
Always remember, the name of any variable, function or class should answer three big questions; why it exists, what it does and what it is used.

Comments do not make up for bad code... Comments are like a double-edged knife. Nothing can be more helpful than a well-placed comment. On the other hand, nothing can clutter up more than frivolous, useless comments that consume space.
A formatted code is a window to your mind. We want people to be impressed by our orderliness, attention to detail and clarity of thought.
If you are thinking that "getting it working" is the first order of business for the professional developer, you cannot be further away from the truth.

title: How To Write Clean Code That Reduces Headaches.
